Patch Set 5:

(27 comments)

Hi, it looks like a chunk of my original comments were not addresses or responded to. I've tried to call out some of the ones I noticed, but I may have missed some. Note some of these are replies to some of the pre-existing chains.

Abandoned

Restart with new round of reviews
Please add large-generator MODP groups?
Please add a comment explaining why this is required (though I understand intuitively why).
We should use a macro for raw constants. I'd suggest trying to find something like NBBY if it's defined (the common value used in the kernel for this).

I usually recommend your own daemonizing routine versus daemon itself. There are a lot of steps that you'll want to use for this that aren't being covered today. See for example the varpd daemonization or the bits that Alex has in progress for rfd 77.
Probably worth making sure close is successful.
Any reason we can't define them in a common header file for consumers then?
Are you sure you want reallocarray and not recallocarray?
I'm not sure what this comment is trying to tell me. What is 'this' in this statement?
So, is it the case that the programmer controls 100% of this and there's no way user related data can influence this?
do we need to explicit_bzero the buffer here even on failure as their could be useful contents still left on the stack, no?

This condition checking seems racy. Shouldn't the act of suspending exclude a resume until the suspend has fully finished? As this is written, someone can come in and start a suspend at this point (assume you get descheduled after releasing the rw lock. If someone else comes in and starts waking up even a single one, you'll never end up hitting the condition.

We should probably make sure worker suspension / resumption is 100% exclusive. In other words a resume should block while a suspend is ongoing and the same is true of the opposite.
Is there a reason semantically that this call does not block for all of the workers to be woken up where as suspend does?
whitespace?
Done
Can we delete this?
Done
I can't find this macro. Is it required?
Why not for everything?

Unless it's changed when this was done (way back), defining that also means that boolean_t uses _B_TRUE, _B_FALSE.  I found being different from the rest of illumos-gate to be rather annoying, so confined the use of the define to just the one file that needed the X/Open sockets (and kept that file rather small to minimize the chance of conflicting definitions).
Can you further elaborate on the comment to explain this?
Yeah, right here.  Would be a shorter line and equally legible if it read (l.sau_sin->sin_addr.s_addr == r->cfa_start4)
Done

It occurs to me that if you're supporting ranges, you can transform a prefix read out of a file into a range and eliminate the CFA_*_PREFIX code altogether.

NOTE:  *Our* IKEv1 didn't support ranges (and IPsec SPD still doesn't), which is why things like ikeadm(1M) have prefixes.  Prefixes are a subset of ranges.  I believe this is why RFC 430x specified them.  (Such a Steve Kent formalism.  :) )

If you have ranges internally, you don't need distinct prefix representation.

Good idea -- I'm all for smaller, simpler code :)

Strange on the ranges -- ike.config(4) states that both 'local_addr' and 'remote_addr' support '<IPaddr/prefix/range>' which I read to mean any one of those three which is why I added support for parsing all three.
Parsing != storing.  You should parse all three.  You should store only as range.

Any reason these are enums instead of #defines that match up with numbers in RFC 7296?

Ahh, because this has to deal with rules/config.  Is a mapping required? Where is this mapping?  (Maybe comment on it?)

Yes -- the existing config file format does not line up with with the ID{i,r} payload allows (RFC7296 only allows a single address -- either IPV4 or IPV6), so a mapping function will need to be written.  This isn't used until the AUTH exchange, but this part is here to allow parsing of an ike.config file (even though this bit is currently ignored since we're only as far as the IKE_SA_INIT exchange).
#defines for easier union member access?  (cfa_start[46], cfa_end[46])?
Done
Same here... name the union members idu_X, and use #defines.
Done

See my other comment, you need multiple remote IDs.

Also, maybe a monotonically increasing rule number to be assigned in here somewhere?
Done
Done

What about remote_id? Shouldn't that have KWF_MULTI? Here's something from "ikeadm dump rule" on my HDC:

REMID: Identity descriptors:
REMID: Includes:
REMID:    emy.joyent.us
REMID:    72.2.118.217
Done
Comment about ECDSA sigs in the future? Or is it omitted to not set expectations?

It's not mentioned in ike.config which is why it's missing.  For now (at least) I just wanted to be able to successfully parse any existing ike.config (with the one exception of adding the 'immediate'Â keyword just to be able to test the IKE_SA_INIT exchange -- that keyword may get removed once the pfkey bits are plumbed in and the AUTH exchange is working.
Also XXX/TODO, one thing people wanted in ike.config(4) was a way to say "oakley_group modp2048" or "oakley_group ecp521".
Excellent idea.
Same here as Oakley group above.  (And does IKEv2 have this?  Or are you keeping it for a possible IKEv1 future?)
Yes -- you can optionally include a DH transform in a IKEV2 as part of establishing a CHILD SA.
And coming soon:  pmsg_osau/pmsg_odau.
Is there a way to do a construction of something like this such that we get the return value? Otherwise, understanding why this failed will be pretty hard.

For some reason, I never saw the VERIFY0() macro which does the same thing (and appears to include the return value if I'm reading it right).  Unless you have objections to that, I'll remove this and replace it's use with VERIFY0.
Given that we may abort, I think it may be clearer to not make this inline, unless you're seeing this show up in a flamegraph.
A port is a uint16_t.
The intention was to use with bunyan which only accepts UINT64, INT64, UINT32, and INT32 (and the value is passed as a vararg), so I wanted to try to minimize lots of casting when using it.

It probably would have been done as a macro, however I've been preferring inline functions to macros since it seems like you get better compile-time checking (and better error messages).  An alternative might be to add BUNYAN_T_SOCKADDR to libbunyan which takes a 'struct sockaddr_storage *' for it's value and prints the 'address:port' -- as that's pretty much what these two macros are used for.

So, I agree 100% with functions over macros. My main point was that I wouldn't prematurely turn this into an inline function unless you believe it's actually going to solve something. You're giving up a bunch of debugability by doing so. If a flamegraph shows that this is hot, then we can always inline it later. But I suspect the crypto costs will dwarf this far and away.
Let's not use NULL and use something that should be an int?

Whoops--cribbed too much from the ss_addr() function :).  I will fix for now -- though obviously if we agree the BUNYAN_T_SOCKADDR suggestion above is better, this (and ss_addr() will end up being removed).
Given that we may abort, I think it may be clearer to not make this inline, unless you're seeing this show up in a flamegraph.
See above -- if we go the BUNYAN_T_SOCKADDR route, this will be removed.  If not I'll move it to a regular function.
Given that we may abort, I think it may be clearer to not make this inline, unless you're seeing this show up in a flamegraph.
Similar answer as other ss_*() functions.
I'd strongly recommend prefixes on these globals. Otherwise trying to find log or port is going to be hard.
my_fmri resides in libipsecutil, which is used by the closed libike.so, so I don't think that one can change, but the others should be able to.
OK. Then let's change the others. Trying to find port is going to be a nightmare.
Per ECC comment below, you'll need to extend this or have a distinct ecc_groups list.

I expect there will need to be adjustments to this file once I can figure out how the ECC related IKEv2 RFCs and PKCS11 map to one another.  Unfortunately, PKCS11 and the IKE RFCs seem to be using different terminology when referring to the various ECC components, PKCS11 seems to want ASN1 OIDs to identify curves, which all makes it look like a bit of a pain to get it working and is probably going to have to take a decent amount of source diving to figure out how the ECC stuff in usr/src/common/crypto is wired up to PKCS11 and then figure out how that maps to the terms used in the IKE RFCs, so I opted to start with just the DH stuff for now since that was significantly more straightforward.

IKEv1 also supports larger-generator groups:

                 22 (MODP 1024-bit, with 160-bit Prime Order Subgroup)
                 23 (MODP 2048-bit, with 224-bit Prime Order Subgroup)
                 24 (MODP 2048-bit, with 256-bit Prime Order Subgroup)

RFC 5114 (which also contains the NIST ECC groups).  No ECC for now either?

See above.  I do plan to have ECC support as part of the minimally viable version, however given the research needed to get ECC working, I figured at least having one that did DH would allow for more play/testing in the meantime, since it's unknown how long it'll take to sort that out (I'm hoping it'll not be too bad, but it's an unknown quantity to me at least -- I also was unsuccessful in trying to find examples).
What if this ends up being invalid?

I'm not sure where the right place would be to add this (since this pops up lots of places -- perhaps as part of the worker big-theory statement), but basically each worker thread gets it's own handle at worker thread creation.  If the session handle creation fails, the thread creation fails, so a worker thread always has a valid PKCS#11 session handle.  I should change this though to just use worker->w_p11h -- the illumos-gate CTF tools have problems with TLS, so originally this was just a small function wrapper around pthread_getspecific().
At least making it a comment in p11h() that explains that it's okay and explains how the pkcs functions will handle that.
Does it really make sense to return zero in the case of a NULL group? Should it be possible for a user to give us a group that doesn't exist?
With the updates to the code, this actually turns out to be a dead function.  It will be removed.
It's here AND in the Makefile?  Why not lose the #ifdef lint?  Or is there some compilation subtlety I'm missing?

I suspect it's old cruft.  I'll take it out for now.  If it needs to go back, I'll try to figure out why specifically and re-add it with a better message -- if I had to guess, perhaps the define wasn't originally getting set in the Makefile when doing lint.
So we're assign a socklen_t to this, which is an unsigned value. I don't think we should use the signed value here.
Done
Why do we have two iovec structs here? Is the second one designed to be an invalid buffer or something? Mostly just asking since iovlen is set to one below.
Not sure.. was possibly old code before I started on it. I'll change it to one and see if it changes anything (recvmsg(3XNET) suggests it should be ok).
Do callers ever call with non-blocking set, if so, should we log if we get EAGAIN?

It should always be blocking.  The socket is waited on by an event port and then this is called (prior to re-associating the socket with the event port).  As far as I know, if a PORT_SOURCE_FD event is received, then you should be able to call recvmsg() on that socket without it being blocked.  Since it's UDP, it each recvmsg() call should correspond to a single datagram.
How does this case happen? How could we return more data than the buffer in question holds?

Honestly, I'm not entirely sure as all the extra socket bits here (minus the bunyan logging) was in the original code dropped from Sun (and I have no clue where any of this is documented, if at all).  I think since it's UDP and this a datagram at a time (i.e. message based, not a stream or any sort of framing concerns), it seems like it's possible that we could receive a datagram larger than the buffer given to hold it).

I found it -- recvmsg(3XNET) -- since these are datagrams, and we block all signals on all inbound threads (we have a dedicated thread that receives all signals for a process and turns them into port events), we cannot be interrupted by a signal, and we must read the entire contents of the datagram in one recvmsg(3XNET) call -- if our buffer is too small, the excess bytes are discarded.

So, the way that the manual page describes this is that the MSG_TRUNC flag will be set when this condition occurs. Are you certain that the actual returned value will be larger than the buffer? This seems to be being derived from the uio_resid field, which will be sized based on the passed in buffer. So I believe that this check will not accomplish what you're intending.
Is this in native host endian and if not, should we be translating fields like the sin6_port to native endian as we go to simplify things for consumers?

I can't find anything definitive, though I thought struct sockaddr_{in,in6} are assumed to store their values in network byte order, so it might be surprising if they're not.  Since JPC doesn't have IPV6, this bit hasn't been tested yet, though it's largely the IPV6 equivalent of the IPV4 code (which has been tested, and whose results are kept in network byte order)
So, you're setting the index down below if its IN6_IS_ADDR_LINKLOCAL or IN6_IS_ADDR_MULTICAST. Should we be doing the reverse up here? Or should that below case change?
I'm surprised mutlicast is below, as we aren't doing any group key management yet.  If this was inherited, I may have brought it all the way intact from racoon2.
Rather than overloading otolen, can we use a boolean_t to track it being set? As otherwise we're going to hit signed / unsigned issues.
Done
Why do you cast here but not above (though hopefully we can get rid of both by making otolen unsigned.
It's unsigned now, so the cast is gone.
Same question here on the number of iovecs.
Done
See comment in the recv function that's related to the reverse setting.
Can we guarantee that this only happens because of programmer error? There's no way a user could get us to use a different family?
Done
Can we put { } around the multi-line if body?
Done
You use uchar_t here, but you're using uint8_t in the source.
Done
You use uchar_t here, but uint8_t in the code. Can we be consistent?
Done
These are using the restrict keyword, which you're not using in the main source code.
Done
This and its header file may need to be left out of minimal-viable IKEv2, but I'll leave that call to another reviewer.
Is this one in 3rd-party license as well?

Include the I-D link for GSA stuff:

https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-yeung-g-ikev2-11
Done
Ahh, now there's a future kernel RFE...
Maybe have (ok && i < ARRAY_SIZE..) instead?
Done
This is the IKEv2 equivalent of p2_pfs in IKEv1's ike.config(4), right?  Should you consult the rule here?

Yes it is the equivalent of the value.  Since it's not part of the acquire function, my thought (this may change once the IKE_AUTH code is written) is that data->ad_dh gets set from the dh parameter in ikev2_sa_match_acquire() which would be given the value from the appropriate rule.
Make a note that ESN needs to be indicated in PF_KEY somehow in the future.
Done
Possibly a bigger-theory statement about how you're using a timer to advance the cookie value?
Done

It's been a while... you need to know the initiator/responder status for packet encoding, but it IS possible for a responder to start a new exchange, right?  (Imagine the responder side has more aggressive soft-lifetime expiration...)

I originally had this wrong, but RFC7296 3.1 explains it better (ISTR that previous versions might not had done as well a job clarifying this):

 *  R (Response) - This bit indicates that this message is a
         response to a message containing the same Message ID.  This bit
         MUST be cleared in all request messages and MUST be set in all
         responses.  An IKE endpoint MUST NOT generate a response to a
         message that is marked as being a response (with one exception;
         see Section 2.21.2).
 *  I (Initiator) - This bit MUST be set in messages sent by the
         original initiator of the IKE SA and MUST be cleared in
         messages sent by the original responder.  It is used by the
         recipient to determine which eight octets of the SPI were
         generated by the recipient.  This bit changes to reflect who
         initiated the last rekey of the IKE SA.

Each side also maintains it's own outbound message ID for new exchanges, and it's possible (and even likely) the two will diverge if one side is initiating more exchanges than the other.  Since lifetimes are managed 'locally' (i.e. not negotiated), whichever side has the smaller lifetimes for SAs (IKE or IPsec) will end up initiating more exchanges, regardless of which side initiated the original IKE SA.

Long-term it's going to be start/end (ranges).  Short-term, it's going to be sadb_address_t (prefixlen + sockaddr) until the theoretical PF_KEYv3 or 2.more-major-changes involving REGISTER flags.  Think about that now, please. We don't want more kernel changes beyond OPS/OPD and 64-bit KMC support.
This probably more appropriate for ike_sa.h, but what if a peer has more than one vendor ID to offer up?

check_vendor() in ike_sa_init.c iterates through all of the VENDOR payloads and sets the vendor type if it sees a vendor payload we recognize (currently just the one I created). I haven't seen anything to date that'd suggest we care too much about values from other implementations (we're just using it ourselves to determine if it's permissible to enforce padding validation on the SK payload), but either way I don't think we'll be too boxed in -- we can always adjust ike_sa_t to have feature flags based on VENDOR payloads if that becomes the case.
Hmmmm. Is there a way to quickly index what's there, and then, in specific-packet-type processing, run a reality check function that consumes the index, and some set of args from the caller?

When we create a packet from a given buffer (i.e. an inbound packet), we create the index of payloads (pkt_t.pkt_payloads and if needed, pkt_t.pkt_payloads_extra) and that verifies all the payload lengthsÂ are sane (since it has to traverse all the payloads to create the index anyway).  My thought was that this would do the first line IKEv2 specific stuff.   I was going to split up the validation for the other exchanges since those can't happen until after the packet's been decrypted and it's ICV has been verified -- we'd still likely want to verify the ISAKMP header and SK payload values before we even attempt decryption or signature validation since it's likely if those are wrong, the decryption or signature validation are going to fail.
Ahh, this could be said indexing function...

No, this just allows us to log a useful summary of the contents of the packet.  The indexing is in pkt.c (since the payload header and packet header are the same for IKEv1 and IKEv2 the thought that those things could use a common implementation, with v1/v2 specific logic added on top and calling the pkt_t functions for the stuff that's common between the two (though most of the IKEv1 stuff is obviously not present yet).
I can't remember... is this reassignment still necessary?

It's mostly to keep things from getting a bit unwieldy.  For every exchange except an IKE_SA_INIT exchange, this is redundant, however for IKE_SA_INIT exchanges, if we are the responder, the local_spi from the inbound packet will always be 0, so we  must reset the value from either the newly created larval IKE SA, or from an existing IKE SA (which would also be larval, but already exists because this packet could be a retransmission or a retry after an INVALID_KE_PAYLOAD response from us).
Refhold of i2sa needed too?
I'll add a comment -- either function (ikev2_sa_get or ikev2_try_new_sa) both return refheld ike_sa_t's that we give to the packet.
Well-commented, thanks.
Thanks :)  Things get so hairy here I really tried to make sure this was as clear as possible, if only for my own sanity.
Do we wish to insert rate-limiting logic here to avoid amplification attacks?  Or is that better done elsewhere?

Possibly.  RFC7296 talks about rate-limiting in the context of unprotected error messages, but isn't clear if a responder MUST retransmit the last response when it receives a retransmit of the last request it received, or if it can throttle the response.  There might be a larger discussion here that might be better done outside of confines of a code review to determine what we want to do, mitigations, etc.
If the answer is no, you'll get lint complaining about len assigned-not-used.
Done
Is this used anywhere?
Yes -- it's used to set the initial size of the buckets in ikev2_sa_init (the thought was that it could potentially be set during startup to override the default).
Likely not worth the time to fix, but this feels redundant given we know init_pkt == NULL ==> initiator, or based in the "I" flag in init_pkt...

Yeah -- that's what I was alluding to in lines 191-193.  This was written prior (the bulk of it years ago) to writing the code for the IKE_SA_INIT exchange (and of course the the IKE SA rekey code has not yet been written), so it wasn't clear at the time if it would be needed or not.  It still may be useful for an IKE SA rekey, so it'd probably be good to revisit once that's done.
Does lint or gcc complain if you compile this 64-bit?  If so, perhaps (.... "0x%016" PRIx64 "", I2SA....) ?
gcc at least doesn't though the PRI* macros are probably a better option, so I'll update it.

Won't i2sa be invalid once refcnt drops from 1 to 0, making this check invalid post-free? You may need to preload a counter or something else... and what else will refhold it?  Shouldn't you just I2SA_REFRELE() once and know it goes away?
Done
Does schedule_timeout() reference-hold the SA, or put another way, do all event-port callbacks need to refrele upon completion?

It depends on what is passed into schedule_timeout() -- Right now it could be a packet or an IKE SA, so it depends on the timeout, also depends on what the callback does -- for example the packet retransmit wouldn't release until the retransmit limit has been reached.
Should be a traversal with lots of ikev2_sa_condemn().  Maybe even suspending packet reception too?
You could rename the argument "remote_spi".  (Did I write this? If so, I apologize...)
Nope, you're innocent :)  I'll fix this.
Same PRIx64 thing as before.
Done
No answers for these questions yet, huh?  BTW, NAT testing is going to be essential, AND I do think we may want to be able to configure the "500" and "4500" to other numbers if need be.
I see three linkages above, does the block comment need to change?

Maybe, though maybe not -- I think I'd like to defer it until after the review -- the newest one was originally intended to be for the worker the IKE SA was bound to.  However if we move away from that as has been talked about, it'll likely go away (and then it wouldn't need to change).
But rm has also done some work (not integrated yet) on porting the kernel rehash bits to user land, which might be useful here, and might change this again, so it might be worth nothing that this needs to be revisited after that has been sorted out if that seems reasonable.
Ahhh... you need to have multiple ones here, or at least acknowledge the possibility of more for the future.

I can add a comment -- it really depends on how we want to utilize the vendor payloads.  Initially, I just wanted a way to be able to determine if we are talking to another instance of our in.ikev2d (vs. someone else's) so we could follow Alex's suggestion of validating the padding in SK payloads.

Why the extra nonce data?  I thought these were used once and thrown away on CREATE_CHILD_SA and AUTH exchanges?

Also, should this be a simple linked list?  (Maybe later after getting-it-to-work?)

Each child SA requires the exchange of nonces, though for the first CHILD SA, the nonces from the IKE_SA_INIT exchange are used for both the IKE SA and the first CHILD SA (created in the AUTH exchange), so I'm guessing (at this point) we'll need a place to stash the nonce values (as I'm unsure at this point how long we'll keep the initial IKE_SA_INIT packets).  Once the IKE_AUTH and CREATE_CHILD_SA exchanges are written, it may turn out they aren't necessary (and they just turn into temporary reminders for myself).

As for the linked list, that was just a guess as to how these will be tracked.  I strongly suspect once the interactions with pf_key as well as any delete informational exchanges are flushed out, that there will be changes here.

Really?!?  This seems unnecessary.  We generate SPIs as opaque 64-bit objects for equality testing only.  Why do any swapping at all?

The ONLY time to swap would be for printing purposes, I'd think.
With the removal of the local-byte-order copy of the header, we just use the values straight from the actual header (which are set when the packet is created).
Per earlier comments, at some point (maybe not now) this will have to become more sophisticated.
It really depends on on how much custom behavior we want to add (either for our own purposes, or as compatibility with other known implementations).  Any values we don't recognize, we just ignore.
Any particular reason to inline these?

Only because they'd otherwise had probably been done as a macro, but I've grown to prefer inline functions over macros when either will work -- they seem to give better compilation error messages, while doing the same thing.
I'd recommend a theory statement around the purpose of an inbound and how it fits into the broader picture of ikev2.

I don't believe you should always continue in the face of failure. There are non-transient conditions that probably indicate we should abort, like:

* EFAULT
* EINAVL
* EBADF
* EBADFD

There maybe others.
Done

So the implementation here isn't quite right. There are also transient failures that you should continue in the front of. You should really be checking errno and acting accordingly. While I suspect that signals are masked form whatever's calling this, if somehow you got an EINTR or similar, then I don't believe we should be aborting. Also, are you sure you want to exit? If you got an EFAULT or anything else, surely you'd want a core dump to figure out why that happened.
Is there a reason that we're not specifying a non-blocking flag in this? If we've been woken up and some other thread somehow also got woken up, won't we end up blocked here?

I don't think it's possible to have two threads woken up on the same socket.  My understanding is that once a socket becomes readable (as we've associated for POLLIN events), it generates a single event, which should be delivered to a single thread amongst those waiting for it.  At that point, no other events should be generated from that socket until it has been re-associated to the event port (which doesn't happen until after we've received the pending message).
I think it's worth a comment here to note that we're re-arming this socket immediately so that other threads can operate.
Done
For the future, if we support outright replacements for 500 and 4500, this will need to adapt...
It appears that this will always bind to the unspecified address of the appropriate family. Is that intentional? Should that be something that's configurable in the zone?

Currently yes -- this follows how the current in.iked works and how it's configuration is specified.  Rules in the configuration file specify which local addresses are used, so one could prevent any  IKE negotiation from occurring on a particular address by omitting any particular addresses.  However there is no reason we can't adjust the behavior and allow for specifying specific addresses (or maybe even interface names as well) with perhaps a default of 'all addresses' if none are specified.

Once the basic functionality was there, I was planning on having some discussions on how to evolve the current configuration format (as used by in.iked) -- both in terms of possible ways of simplifying the work involved for a standard, sane configuration (for some to-be-determined definition of standard and sane), for ease of integration within Triton, and because IKEv2 explicitly supports remote access VPN, we would want additional configuration support for that eventually (though probably not part of that minimum functional version discussed).

> this follows how the current in.iked works and how it's configuration is specified.

Nope.  The current in.iked (because it does NOT do sendfromto()/recvfromto()) queries the routing socket for available local IPs and binds to each one.  Do "pfiles `pgrep iked`" sometime and have a look.

To restate it slightly differently, in.iked doesn't have any documented way of binding to specific addresses, suggesting it listens on all ports (as a side note, querying the routing socket seems a bit of a peculiar way to get the list of addresses vs. getifaddrs()
I'd strongly recommend prefixes on these.
On non-debug I recommend always turning on the "guards" settings. Given the security sensitivity of this daemon, we should be willing to pay the extra cost for that.
Done
Why are we ignoring the return value?

Why do we use the BE macros here versus the hton macros elewhere?

The payload structures are internally aligned (i.e. the offsets of the fields of a given payload struct align how you would expect), however there is no guarantee the payload itself starts on an aligned boundary, and there is no way we can pad it to align it.  So we can freely dereference locally defined instances of the struct, but (for portability) need to use the BE_IN* macros when referencing pointers into a packet.

These structures (proposals, transforms, transform attributes) all embed like a russian doll (proposals inside the payload, transforms inside proposals, and transform attributes inside transforms).  Each of these structures have a length field that includes all of the embedded structures, so as we add each one, we have to update successive length fields, none of which are guaranteed to be aligned.

It's not clear to me how the BE_IN16 macros are actually helping with this. Aren't you assuming that the address taken in those macros are actually aligned? If you want to guarantee alignment, isn't the only way to actually bcopy the data elsewhere? Are the casting games that these macros play actually accurate?

The intention is that you can use this to iterate through payloads of a given type via something like 'for (pay = pkt_get_payload(pkt, IKEV2_PAYLOAD_VENDOR); pay != NULL; pay = pkt_get_payload(pkt, IKEV2_PAYLOAD_VENDOR, pay)) { ... }', so we need to start looking for the next payload of the given type starting after the one we just returned.

SPIs are either 64-bit values (for IKE) or 32-bit for AH and ESP (as well as fibre-channel, though we don't support encrypted fibre-channel).  The spilen value is determined based on the type of SA we're dealing with, so not directly from user input.  In certain instances, no SPI value is added and the values from the IKE packet header are used instead, so the only valid values are 8, 4, or 0.

My understanding of how C99 inline functions work is that you have to specify a 'parking lot' (for lack of a better term) where it will put the code of an inline function in case the compiler decides to not inline a function (since barring compiler flags indicating otherwise, inline is by default treated as a hint).
I have to admit, this makes me feel somewhat dubious about the decision to inline these functions. Is the debugability tradeoff really worth it?

Unfortunately, IKE doesn't align any of their structures, so aside from the initial header, every structure can have arbitrary alignment within the packet (and the structures are defined such that we cannot add our own padding to force alignment).  The BE_OUTnn macros appear to be explicitly for dereferencing potentially unaligned pointers, while I don't believe htobe32() would.  This is probably a moot point for X86 which doesn't care about alignment, but it'd be needly making things harder to port to any future platforms that do.

The short answer (which I'll elaborate on in the additional comments) is that this is what takes the DH/EC shared key and nonce payloads to generate a pseudo-random stream for a given SA (either IKE, AH, or ESP) whose output are the keys used for encryption and signing.  As such, the lifetime of a prfp_t is just the lifetime of the calling function (each new SA will have a new prfp_t initialized with new values).
Should we check that p11h() didn't return CK_INVALID_HANDLE before calling this?
See the other comments -- this is only called by worker threads (I can add a VERIFY to that), which must have a PKCS#11 session handle assigned to them at creation, so this can never fail.

PCKS#11 is not very clear, though looking at the pkcs11_softtoken implementation, it appears a failure resets the state, so should be unnecessary.
Is it possible for tlen to be zero after this or is that guaranteed by prfplus_update()?

The prfplus_update() function generates a new block (of size prfp->prop_tbuflen) of data and resets prfp->prfp_pos (the position within the block) to 0, so it cannot.  In reality, tlen is always equal to prfp->prfp_tbuflen at this point, though it was set this way mostly just for consistency with how tlen (how much is left in the current block) is calculated at the top of the loop at line 167.

CKM_INVALID_MECHANISM (aka. 0xffffffff, -1, or MAX_UINT32) may be more appropriate here.

There is no provision in PKCS#11 to indicate 'no or unknown mechanism type' -- there is CKR_MECHANISM_VALID, but PKCS#11 appears to treat the mechanism IDs and return values as distinct ID spaces, so returning a CKR_ value when one is expecting a CKM_ value is probably wrong.

The problem is there's no currently defined PKCS#11 mechanism for those PRFs.  We could probably just make those 'INVALID("unsupported PRF function")' as the SA negotiation code should never allow us to agree upon a PRF we don't support (if it does, it is an application bug).

Why do we assume that we can't get an interrupt or other short read?

All signals for the process are handled by a single detached thread (that then delivers them as user events to the main thread via port_send(3C).  random(7D) says that the read should block until the requested amount of data is available (unless it's set non-blocking, which we do not do there), so there should be no other way short of a fatal error (ENXIO) that the read should fail.

What is when supposed to represent? Based on callers it seems like te_time - now will in the general case be negative because we've processed it which means that te_time was less than a previous in time now.

This should be signed -- it's how long (in ms) from now when the event will fire.  The only time this might be negative though is when processing the timers.  When creating or cancelling timers, they have not fired yet, so te->te_time should usually be in the future (it is possible that something scheduled _very_ soon in the future might pass it's deadline between the time the event was created and when it was logged, which means it'll fire on the next time through the worker loop).
This is going to be a call generator. If it gets called every time we process events and it ends up negative that's going to be very confusing.

Do you know why we need to define all these here?

Looking it back up, these should actually be 'extern inline', not just 'extern'.

Like the other inline functions, the compiler will instantiate a non-inline version of the functions for instances where it cannot inline a call to them.  Unlike C++ where it happens randomly (or possibly multiple times in different compilation units), with C99 one has to explicitly indicate where the non-inlined versions should go, which is what these statements do.  These are all used in lieu of macros since they can usually give much nicer error messages on compilation errors than macros.

do we need to explicit_bzero the buffer here even on failure as their could be useful contents still left on the stack, no?

This condition checking seems racy. Shouldn't the act of suspending exclude a resume until the suspend has fully finished? As this is written, someone can come in and start a suspend at this point (assume you get descheduled after releasing the rw lock. If someone else comes in and starts waking up even a single one, you'll never end up hitting the condition.

We should probably make sure worker suspension / resumption is 100% exclusive. In other words a resume should block while a suspend is ongoing and the same is true of the opposite.
Is there a reason semantically that this call does not block for all of the workers to be woken up where as suspend does?
